sentences_tone.text: AMD Is Losing Its War With Nvidia - NVIDIA Corporation (NASDAQ:NVDA) | Seeking AlphaSign in / Join NowGO»Market NewsStock IdeasDividendsMarket OutlookInvesting StrategyETFs & FundsEarningsPROLong IdeasShort IdeasCramer's PicksIPOsQuick PicksSectorsEditor's PicksAMD Is Losing Its War With NvidiaNov.12.16 | About: NVIDIA Corporation (NVDA) Mark Hibben Follow Long only, tech, chipmakers, softwareSend MessageSummaryThe Q3 earnings results of AMD and Nvidia provide a stark financial contrast.While Nvidia demonstrates enormous growth and profitability, AMD's Computing and Graphics segment has been relatively stagnant and unprofitable.Another stark contrast exists between the reality of AMD's performance this year and the expectations and beliefs of AMD fans and investors.For over a year, Advanced Micro Devices (NYSE:AMD) has fought a war with Nvidia (NASDAQ:NVDA), its principal weapon being Polaris architecture GPUs.
It has been a war fought not only for the hearts and minds of PC users and gamers, but for investors as well.
It has been a dirty little war, full of mudslinging against anyone who dared offer the slightest criticism of AMD.
As the recent earnings reports of the companies makes clear, it is a war that AMD is losing.
This was probably inevitable, since it could never have been won based on propaganda alone.

Click to enlarge Source: Google Finance The AMD Fan Litany SA contributor The Structure of Price recently wrote an article that I found interesting for its title: "AMD: The Coming Technology War With Nvidia".
My immediate reaction was that the war is already on, and it's been going on for more than a year.
I know because I've been in the trenches of it.
Ever since I wrote AMD's Classic Death Spiral last year, my AMD articles have received considerable attention from AMD fans and regularly receive the most comments of any of my articles.
Early in the year, the comments were still fairly thoughtful and on-topic.
That began to change by the Q1 earnings report, in which AMD reported a 19% y/y decline in revenue and an operating loss of $68 million.

In response to my article on the report, AMD: A Triumph of Faith, the comments descended into dismissive personal attacks:
User thegunguy: Here we go again, someone writing about tech that doesn't understand tech.
AMD GPU's are competing if not better than Nvidia's offering.
If zen ends up being viable, AMD is really going to take off.
User trader_xx: mark hibben has no idea about when stocks change from trader bait to buy and hold.
dont expect anything meaningful from a guy who spews 3 articles a day.
Again, thegunguy: Fairly Certain he pays SA for his articles.
In fact, I don't think I've ever managed to write three articles in a day, and I certainly don't pay SA to publish my articles.
SA always pays me.
Always.
This is just a small sample.
Throughout the year, the comments have continued to devolve into the techniques of online bullying, ridicule and name calling, as if it was thought that this would deter me from writing about AMD.

Here's a sample of comments to my article AMD And 3 Other Case Studies In Tech Business Decline: User trader_xx
Woohoo another strong finish up 6.9% !
Hibben never disappoints...Unless one actually reads the article.

User buddmann: Long on blowing smoke up peoples arses User thegunguy: yeah his articles are click bait And this is just a sample of the 301 comments the article received that made it through moderation.
I also started to receive expletive filled hate messages through the SA messaging system from anonymous users, which I will spare the reader.
I also began to see my name mentioned in articles critical of AMD by other SA contributors.
For instance, in a recent article by Claudio Rizzini, I'm mentioned no less than six times in the comments.

A sample: User Fernando Garrido:
Claudio, you again?
there must really be fear, 2 hibben + 2 of you in just a week, this is really getting poised for 8$ and resilient to "corrections".
EOW 8+, it's my prediction.
counting with the hibben rizzini effect and we're all sure now!
In fact, there's never been any concern on my part about AMD posing a threat to Nvidia, or even about the heaps of abuse I've received from AMD fans.
I always thought that it was a mistake for them to draw so much attention to me.
Furthermore, notoriety is always better than obscurity in this business, so the fans were actually doing me a service.
I expected the strategy to backfire once it started to become clear that AMD wasn't even getting close to living up to the fans' expectations.

Stark Financial Contrast And with the release of Nvidia's fiscal 2017 Q3 earnings on November 10, it is becoming clear, even to the AMD fans, that the fantasy of AMD crushing Nvidia this year needs to be abandoned, at the very least.
Nvidia posted record revenue of $2.004 billion, which was up 54% y/y.
GAAP operating income was up 130% to $708 million.
Revenue from Nvidia's GPU business alone was $1.697 billion, up 53% for the year, and more than AMD's total revenue for 2016 Q3 of $1.307 billion.
Nvidia's revenue from gaming applications of its GPUs was $1.244 billion, up 63% y/y and up 59% sequentially.
In contrast, AMD's Computing and Graphics revenue was $472 million, up 10% y/y, and 8% sequentially.
Furthermore, Computing and Graphics posted an operating loss of $66 million for the quarter.

During the Nvidia conference call, CFO Colette Kress made it very clear that strength in gaming reached to all price tiers: Gaming revenue crossed the $1 billion mark and increased 63% year-on-year to a record $1.24 billion, fueled by our Pascal-based GPUs.
Demand was strong in every geographic region across desktop and notebook, and across the full gaming audience, from GTX 1050 to the TITAN X. GeForce gaming PC notebooks recorded significant gains.
Our continued growth in the GTX gaming GPUs reflects the unprecedented performance and efficiency gains in the Pascal architecture.

Although AMD garnered much interest and sympathy for its approach of starting at the lower end of the graphics card price range with the initial Polaris add-in boards, in fact, this clearly hasn't worked from a profitability standpoint.
Nvidia shut AMD off from the high-end of the graphics card market.
Nvidia captured a huge amount of profit while AMD was forced to take a loss in its Computing and Graphics segment.
With the introduction of the lower priced GTX 1050 cards, even the low end ceased to be a refuge for AMD.
AMD's approach did work from the standpoint of increasing unit market share in Q2, but it's not clear that it will continue to work for Q3.
The enormous gains that Nvidia made in its fiscal Q3 suggest that AMD gave back some market share in calendar Q3.
We'll see.

Investor Takeaway As the reader may have noticed above, one persistent theme of the AMD fans has been to cite the market movement of AMD this past year as validation for themselves and invalidation of my opinion of AMD.

With the recent gain of Nvidia following the earnings report of nearly 30% on November 11, even this is becoming a little tired, as shown in the chart at the start of the article The stark contrast in financial performance will not serve to deter AMD fans much in the near term, and I don't expect the stock to suffer due to Nvidia's results.
The attention of the fans is now fixed on the future AMD products, Zen, and Vega, that are promised to achieve in 2017 what could not be achieved this year.
Of course, until the products come out, there will always be some room for hope.
However, my basic thesis regarding AMD remains unchanged.
AMD is simply outgunned by its more profitable and better capitalized competitors Nvidia and Intel (NASDAQ:INTC).
For instance, AMD's R&D budget for Q3 of $259 million is dwarfed by Nvidia's at $373 million and Intel's at $3.069 billion.
There's a belief among the fans that AMD can outperform its competitors despite being heavily outspent.
The reality of the chip design world belies this.
Talented chip designers are at a serious premium and they can write their own ticket, anywhere.
They naturally gravitate towards the companies that offer the richest compensation packages.
That's not AMD.
I fully expect AMD fans to keep bidding up the price of the stock as the AMD hype machine goes into overdrive in advance of the release of Vega and Zen.
Therefore, I still consider the stock a reasonable momentum play and a hold.
It's not where I'm putting my money, however, since I bet on tangible results, not wishful thinking.
I remain long Nvidia and recommend it as an unqualified buy.
Disclosure: I am/we are long NVDA.
I wrote this article myself, and it expresses my own opinions.
I am not receiving compensation for it (other than from Seeking Alpha).
